title: 104_hr3992
content: The "Medicare Commission Act of 1996" is established under this Act. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program is established with 15 members appointed by the President and Senate leaders. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by the President and Senate leaders. The members are selected by the Majority Leader and Speaker of the House, with specific guidelines on political party representation and timing of appointments. The Commission, consisting of 15 members, must be appointed within 3 months of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the life of the Commission, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, and meetings are called by the Chairman. A majority of members constitutes a quorum, and the Commission selects a Chairman from among its members. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with reviewing analyses of Medicare trust funds, identifying threats to their solvency, analyzing potential solutions, and providing recommendations to ensure financial integrity and provision of health benefits under the Medicare Program. The Commission is responsible for reviewing Medicare trust funds, identifying solvency threats, analyzing solutions, and making recommendations to maintain financial integrity and health benefits under the Medicare Program. The term "Medicare trust funds" refers to the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund. The Commission must submit a report to the President and Congress within 12 months of its first meeting. Congressional consideration of legislation will follow the Commission's report. The Majority Leader of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, in consultation with the Minority Leaders, must develop legislation within 3 months for the long-term solvency of Medicare trust funds. If not voted upon within 3 months, the legislation will receive privileged consideration. If legislation for Medicare trust funds is not voted on in the House of Representatives within 3 months, the committee will be discharged from consideration, and a motion to proceed with the legislation will be allowed. In the House, a motion to proceed with legislation is highly privileged. In the Senate, if legislation is not voted on within 3 months, the committee is discharged, and a motion to proceed with the legislation is allowed. In the Senate, a motion to proceed to consider legislation is privileged. If legislation is not voted on within 3 months, a joint resolution can be moved to endorse commission recommendations. In the House of Representatives, a motion can be made to consider a joint resolution endorsing commission recommendations and providing legislative authority to implement them. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. Additionally, the Commission has authority over personnel matters. The Commission members who are federal government officers or employees serve without additional compensation. Private citizens on the Commission also serve without pay, but they are reimbursed for travel expenses. Government officials serving on the Commission receive travel expenses, including per diem, at authorized rates. The Chairman has the authority to appoint necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can provide administrative support upon request. The Chairman appoints an executive director for the Commission, with compensation set by the Chairman. Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status and privileges. The Chairman of the Commission can also procure temporary and intermittent services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its report. Expenses will be covered by funds available to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
